messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Brinkley available on line
messages.msgSnippet: I went through this site over the weekend and someone must have had a lot of spare time on their hands LOL. I get board after doing 10 scans, this would have
messages.messageBody:
I went through this site over the weekend and someone must have had a lot of spare time on their hands LOL. I get board after doing 10 scans, this would have taken weeks to put together. One thing it has done for me is made me want to buy the books now.

Cheers Jim, this is cool

Rich
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, November 24, 2003 11:25 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Brinkley available on line


Milt,
Of course Brinkley is readily available in paper. I posted it because the subject matter is somewhat topical, but more because it is about as good a presentation of the "scanned page" approach as I've seen. For those thinking about making texts available on line, it's worth checking this out. I agree with you that it is not a very usable way to present the material. I could suffer through it if it was the only way to access a text, but better methods should be used if at all possible.

Again, http://tinyurl.com/w67b is the place to look.

Jim


---

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Brinkley available on line
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Of course Brinkley is readily available in paper.  I posted it because the subject matter is somewhat topical, but more because it is about as good a
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
Of course Brinkley is readily available in paper. I posted it because the subject matter is somewhat topical, but more because it is about as good a presentation of the "scanned page" approach as I've seen. For those thinking about making texts available on line, it's worth checking this out. I agree with you that it is not a very usable way to present the material. I could suffer through it if it was the only way to access a text, but better methods should be used if at all possible.

Again, http://tinyurl.com/w67b is the place to look.

Jim
----

Jim und all,
Once in a while, you can find Cpt. Brinkley's volumes in e-bay.
I got my set there, different editions but the text/illustrations are
the same .
It is easier to leaf through the actual books than to click, scroll,
click, scroll again und again.........
just my personal experience, of course.


Milt



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Brinkley available on line
messages.msgSnippet: And they do offer the volume discussing tsuba and sword furniture: Captain F. Brinkley, Japan - Its History Arts and Literature, Volume VII, Pictorial And
messages.messageBody:
And they do offer the volume discussing tsuba and sword furniture:

Captain F. Brinkley, Japan - Its History Arts and Literature, Volume VII, Pictorial And Applied Art, Chapter VI, "Sculpture on Sword Furniture," J.B. Millet, Boston & Tokyo, 1901.
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, November 22, 2003 9:27 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Brinkley available on line


I just started checking out this site and found that they have full scans of at least some volumes of Captain Brinkley's 1901 "Oriental Series."

http://tinyurl.com/w67b


I've been looking through volume one and the quality of the scans is quite good. Anyone who has been talking about making books available on line should check it out for the navigation experience. Of course the content is classic, too. Be aware that every page is scanned, even blank ones, so it takes a bit of clicking to get to the beginning of the text... about 19 pages in.

Jim

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
